comments.raw_comment:
We evaluated a 2022 graph titled “World electricity generation” by Ember. We noticed that it displayed the types and amounts of energy used throughout the world as a whole from 2000 to the 2020s. There were also separate graphs that specifically documented the energy usage of the United States, China, and India over the same time period. We noted that the overall energy usage worldwide for all types is going up, and that nuclear is the most prominent energy source while coal is the least prominent. We also noticed that there were “dips” in worldwide energy usage around 2008 and 2020, which probably correspond with the economic hardships caused by the 2008 housing crisis and the coronavirus pandemic. 

 

We wonder what the data looked like before 2000, as “clean” energy seems to be a relatively new phenomenon. We also wonder why India’s energy usage is so low when compared to the United States and China.

 

This topic is important because we all use energy every day, and it is useful to know the main types of energy being used. It also gives more insight into how different countries operate.

 

Our title for the graph is “Ember’s Evaluation of the Evolution of Electricity.”

This graph shows the World's Electricity Generation from 2000-2022, specifies where this energy is derived from, and if that energy is clean or fossil. I notice that there are more gigawatt hours of fossil electricity such as gas, oil, and coal than clean electricity. This is expected given the global warming crisis that we are currently facing as a result of these fossil fuels being emitted into the air in order to generate electricity. However, I also noticed that clean energy has significantly increased since 2000, especially wind and solar electricity which faced a significant increase. As climate change has become a more real and pressing issue over the past couple of years, there has been a bigger push to use renewable energy such as putting solar panels on your roof. The more specific graphs demonstrate electric generation in countries like China, India, and the U.S. I noticed that China used significantly more electricity than India even though they have the same population. China also generates most of its electricity through coal. This makes sense considering how industrialized China is and how many factories it needs to upkeep. I can infer this is why China has such bad air quality and pollution. The graph of the U.S. concerns me because while our population is much less than India's, we still use more electricity than them. I wonder what other innovations we will develop to limit fossil electricity generation.
"The Future is Clean!"

comments.raw_comment: This graph charts the source of the world’s electricity supply based on the method of its production--that is, whether the electricity was produced via fossil fuel consumption in the form of oil, gas, and coal; or, if clean sources like hydroelectric, wind, solar, and nuclear power were used in production. The lion’s share of global power production, as the graph indicates, originates in the burning of coal, and, more broadly, other fossil fuels. This is despite an evident recent uptick in reliance on clean energy sources, perhaps spurred on by recent ecocentric movements and such measures as the Paris Accords. Indeed, the pressures to which such a move responds seem pressing, so much so that the global predominance of coal energy sources--which produce the greatest amount of and therefore most harmful greenhouse emissions--incites no little concern. This concerning trend finds further grounding in the subsequent graphs included below, wherein the global energy consumption is broken apart into a few constituent countries’. The graph evinces that China, one of the world’s foremost economic and industrial superpowers, remains largely dependent on coal energy for its massive energy consumption, around twice that of the United States. The unfortunate truth of such statistics is that overreliance on coal does not only affect the country producing it, but has devastating environmental ramifications for the entire world.

This graph shows the world’s electrical energy resources and how much is estimated to have been used from 2000 to 2022. Those resources being shown include nuclear, gas, coal, wind, solar, oil, hydroelectric, and others. The second graph shows how much of those resources are being used in various countries. Overall, the world has seen a steady increase in the use of the noted resources to power electricity.  Mostly so in nuclear power which was used around 15 million gigawatt hours in 2000 and jumped to surpassing 25 million gigawatt hours in 2020. The first thing that popped out to me about these graphs was the sheer amount of energy generation produced by China. In just the coal industry, China uses more energy than the US uses in all industries combined. Another thing that interested me was the steady proportion of nuclear energy throughout the years. Nuclear power has gone through many recent developments making it extremely less dangerous for the environment, but those advancements aren't reflected in its usage. With issues such as clean energy, I wonder how strongly connotations surrounding certain types of energy effect their usage on large scales. Wind and solar energy appears to be the "least" clean form of clean energy according to the graphs, but among the three main types of clean energy, it is the only form that has seen a large increase in usage over time. Though it could also be due to the fact that nuclear and hydroelectric plants both require large amounts of space and infrastructure in order to construct and maintain. 
Being informed about this information is very important because of the prevalence of energy discussions. Hearing debates and making conclusions from there is an incomplete way of developing a strategy for energy moving forward. By seeing how much each country relies on each form of energy, you are better equipped to talk about how those infrastructures could be changed to better the world going forward.

Immediately, I noticed how a stacked area chart is being utilized to visualize the data presented. The issue with using a stacked area chart like these graphs is that it is difficult to determine the actual size of one section in the chart since each section is built on top of one another like layers of sediment. This also makes it difficult to visually see trends in specific sections since their baselines are all different and affected by the layers below. I also noticed how it appears clean energy sources have increased in the past 22 years, specifically how much wind and solar have exploded recently. 
I wonder how the U.S. has stayed fairly consistent with energy production when it feels as if electricity has become more and more integral to life each day in the twenty-first century. Similarly, on the opposite side, why has China’s production boomed so much?
These graphs relate to me and my community because as climate change continues and natural fossil fuels begin to run out, the need for sustainable energy sources and better energy consumption practices is more important than ever. Keeping energy use steady, or even decreasing is something that we as a community should strive for. Additionally, by making sure we continue to switch more and more to clean energy production, we are helping the prosperity and longevity of the planet and our own futures. 
Title: “A Decade of the World’s Energy: Is Clean Power the Future?”

The biggest thing that stands out to me from the four graphs is the increasing usage of coal power in China. In recent years, there's been a large global push towards clean energy in response to severe climate change, but these global trends don't appear whatsoever in China. In fact, the total coal usage from China is more than the total energy usage in the US. This makes sense from a population stand point, but looking at the graphs with that perspective makes me wonder why India's total energy usage is so low compared to China and the US, especially when the population of India is about the same as the population of China, which is much larger than the US. These graphs also make me wonder about how effective global initiatives can really be if there are still large nations not meeting the regulations designed to help clean our planet.
Understanding how our nation produces the energy that we've grown to rely on helps contextualize issues regarding our energy grid. Ideas of severely reducing one form of energy versus another need to be backed by the knowledge of how we are currently relying on that energy. Simply making decisions or forming ideas without knowledge of the implications will lead to ignorant and damaging decisions.
For a title of the graphs, you could use 
"What Powers the People? Energy Production Across the Years"

What I notice:
Coal has consistently been the largest source of global electricity generation, though it has declined slightly since 2010. Gas, wind and solar, and other renewables have been steadily increasing since 2000. Nuclear and hydro have stayed relatively flat over the 20 year period. Fossil fuels (coal, gas, oil) still make up the vast majority of electricity generation compared to clean sources.

What I wonder:
How much have total global electricity generation amounts changed over this period? The graph shows share but not absolute amounts. What explains the slight dip in coal around 2020 - was it due to the pandemic reducing energy demand? How much variability is there between countries and regions in the electricity source mix? How are these trends projected to change in the coming decades as renewables scale up further?

Impact on me and my community:
The still-dominant share of fossil fuels has major climate change and air pollution impacts that affect the whole world. More renewables means cleaner air and reduced emissions, but also potential economic disruption in fossil-dependent communities. The trends point to the need to massively scale up clean energy investment and infrastructure in my community and globally.

From 2000 to 2020 there seems to be a decrease in coal, an small but noticeable increase in wind and solar, and then an increase in oil. As the graph depicts energy usage from 2000 to 2020, I am able to observe if me and my family's energy usage coorelates with the graph. Over the last 20 years many families in my neighborhood, including my own, added solar panels to their roofs, this lines up fairly accurately with when solar and wind power starts to increase (around 2010). I am glad to see this change, however I unfortunately also observe that with the layout of my suburban town, driving is almost essential to go to places so seeing an increase in oil also makes sense. These graphs should encourage people to cut out oil, if they need to go somewhere close and walking/biking is a feasible means of travel then they should consider that instead.
